results.title: Futura, a King of Graffiti, Returns to His Roots
results.abstract: The artist has gone from painting subway cars to the runways of Comme des Garçons. After a hiatus, his two exhibitions are his first in his hometown in 30 years.

multimedia.caption: The graffiti artist Futura, born Leonard McGurr, near the Eric Firestone Gallery in Manhattan, where “Futura 2020,” his first solo exhibition in New York in 30 years, is on view.

results.title: This Was the Year When Everything Became TV
results.abstract: As a global pandemic left us homebound, cousin Emily in Pittsburgh existed on the same plane as “Emily in Paris.”

results.title: Carnegie Hall Stands By Its Chairman, Despite Tax Violations
results.abstract: Robert F. Smith has acknowledged his involvement in a 15-year scheme to hide more than $200 million in income and evade taxes, but he retains the support of the hall’s board.

multimedia.caption: Robert F. Smith at Carnegie Hall’s Opening Night Gala Dinner on Oct. 3, 2019. The chairman of the Carnegie Hall board, he has retained the support of other members after he acknowledged having evaded income taxes.
multimedia.copyright: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Robert F. Smith at Carnegie Hall’s Opening Night Gala Dinner on Oct. 3, 2019. The chairman of the Carnegie Hall board, he has retained the support of other members after he acknowledged having evaded income taxes.

results.title: Johns Hopkins Reveals That Its Founder Owned Slaves
results.abstract: The university and its medical system have long celebrated their founding benefactor as a staunch abolitionist. But newly surfaced documents tell a different story.

multimedia.caption: Johns Hopkins University announced research indicating that its founding benefactor and namesake, long celebrated as an abolitionist, owned enslaved people.

results.title: Jackson Pollock, Before the Drip
results.abstract: “Mural,” his largest painting, is back in New York for the first time in 20 years, at the Guggenheim.

multimedia.caption: Jackson Pollock’s 20-foot-wide “Mural”(1943), originally commissioned by Peggy Guggenheim and now owned by the University of Iowa. He structured the composition with seven more or less vertical arcs of brown-to-black, which encourages you to read it horizontally, like a narrative panorama.
multimedia.copyright: The Pollock-Krasner Foundation/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

results.title: Sara Leland, Ballerina of Passion and Abandon, Dies at 79
